awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Exploring Impacts of Cascading Failure and Recovery Efforts of Interdependent Critical Infrastructure in Socially Vulnerable Puerto Rican Communities After Hurricane Fiona
awd_abstract_narration:
Hurricane Fiona severely impacted Southwestern Puerto Rico, provoking landslides, unleashing flooding across the Island, and obliterating the power grid. Such impacts are quite unusual for a Category 1 hurricane, raising concerns about disaster-preparedness of the US Territory that faces a multilayered socioeconomic crisis rooted in long-standing policy, migration, and poor budget practices. While it is well-known that disasters and subsequent recovery efforts exacerbate the socioeconomic disparities among marginalized groups, there is a lack of understanding of how these groups are being impacted by the cascading critical infrastructure (CI) failures and delays in the restoration process. While the role of CI interdependencies has gained importance for analyzing cascading failures, their linkage to restoration activities after a hurricane and the compounding effect on community recovery have not yet been extensively studied or systematically documented. This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) award supports the collection of time-sensitive data to study the impacts of cascading hurricane-induced failures of electric and transportation networks on socially vulnerable Puerto Rican communities and to understand the relationships between CI restoration activities and faster community recovery. The research findings will fill an important data gap for the development of community-based multi-infrastructure optimal recovery and reconstruction strategies.

This research will quantify the impacts of cascading failures of power grid and transportation systems on socially vulnerable communities and capture the dynamic relationships of CI restoration interdependencies with the community recovery process. In addition to data collected from publicly available sources, the research team will conduct interviews and focused-group surveys of the emergency managers and infrastructure operators to understand the multidimensional impacts on the hardest-hit Puerto Rican communities and investigate how the restoration decisions are associated with the challenges and resource constraints. The team will also conduct a focused-group survey of the households from communities of high social vulnerability to document their actual and perceived harms owing to hurricane-induced infrastructure failure and the delayed community recovery. This project will generate valuable information to better inform decision-makers to anticipate future disruptions in CI systems and plan for efficient and equitable restoration strategies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

This RAPID project focused on collecting timely data after 2022 Hurricane Fiona in Puerto Rico to understand the (i) impact of the hurricane-induced failure of the electric grid and transportation systems on the socially vulnerable Puerto Rican communities, (ii) the restoration interdependencies of the critical infrastructures (CIs), and (iii) their associations with the post-disaster community recovery efficiency. The research team collected fieldwork data that uncovered the dimensions of these CI failures, detected areas of highest social vulnerability, and the recovery efforts and challenges after the hurricane. 

Two faculty and two Ph.D. students traveled for nine days to Puerto Rico during the Spring of 2023 to interview experts, emergency managers, and community groups. The team interviewed ten representatives from the government's official disaster response team, the transportation authorities, the private sector, municipalities, community associations, and the academic communities. These interviews discussed the decision-making process to recover and restore critical infrastructure services, the associated challenges for a faster and more efficient recovery of the communities, and lessons learned from the aftermath of a hurricane-like natural hazard based on the experiences gained from the recent Hurricane Fiona. The team visited communities in Caguas, Salinas, Jayuya, Adjuntas, Utuado, and Mayaguez, conducting focus group interviews. They collected 40 household surveys to explore the households' perceived impacts due to CI failure and restoration delays. Before the fieldwork, the team also collected data from publicly available datasets and newspaper articles to identify areas with prolonged outages, property and infrastructure damage, and flooding due to Hurricane Fiona. The integrated dataset also captured information about restoration interdependencies. Altogether, the efforts translated into developing a comprehensive RAPID data collection and analysis framework that integrates qualitative and quantitative data to explore disaster impacts on CIs, restoration interdependencies of CIs, and the effects on the most socially vulnerable communities.

Intellectual Merit

The main contribution of this research is the empirical understanding of the impact of cascading CI failures on people's socioeconomic vulnerabilities and the restoration interdependencies between the CIs that would further inform post-disaster response and recovery efforts in Puerto Rico. The research team collected unique and timely data to develop an understanding that would help inform decision-makers towards restoration efforts of the power grid and transportation systems in post-disaster environments. As a result, the team published a synthesized fieldwork dataset and connected existing datasets that the team has made available for researchers using the DesignSafe platform. The interdisciplinary team of experts included researchers from the University at Buffalo who studied critical infrastructure and community resilience after natural hazards and local partners who were actively involved with post-disaster restoration efforts. The team was able to develop a network of disaster management teams, nonprofits and community associations, infrastructure managers, local and federal agencies, academic experts, and community leaders from all over Puerto Rico, which will serve as a critical resource for future projects on advancing community resilience.

Broader Impacts

This study targeted socially vulnerable communities and studied their perspectives on critical infrastructure delays. The research work directly benefits Puerto Rican communities, whose voices and perspectives were fundamental to this study. Mitigating such impacts goes beyond Puerto Rican communities as the main findings will likely influence socially vulnerable communities located in regions all across the U.S. that share common features with Puerto Rico (e.g., Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, Texas, and the Carolinas) and the Caribbean Sea, where hurricanes and other related hazards constantly hit their territories. The data and analysis developed could better inform disaster response efforts that prioritize the well-being of the most vulnerable populations. The broader impacts of the project also extend to the scientific contribution to the community by publishing the fieldwork data on the restoration efforts after Hurricane Fiona. The team produced and made available their project findings through a website that includes links to publicly available datasets and codes for processing the collected aggregate data. The research team has disseminated these tools through workshops, conferences, and direct communications with the Puerto Rican community. The educational impacts include the training of four Ph.D. students; two of them visited Puerto Rico in the Spring of 2023, and the other two students helped process data collected in the Fall of 2023. One master's and two undergraduate students were involved in data post-processing as well. The data provided support for the completion of one Ph.D. thesis. Two of the graduate students were Spanish-speaking Hispanic. Other dissemination plans include publishing at least two peer-reviewed journal papers, two conference proceedings, and six conference-invited talks.
